Dear Ms. Sperling:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 12/4/19.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and ISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of four reevaluations did not make a licensing
recommendation to the department at least 15 days before the
expiration of the foster home license. A corrective action plan is
required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days
of its completion.
One of three special evaluations reviewed did not provide the
foster parent a copy of the report with 10 calendar days of its
completion. A corrective action plan is required.
4

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.16.3 - Page 23 Relative Foster Parents (Commitment 52).
(a) When placing a child with a relative who has not been previously licensed as a
foster parent, DHHS shall:
(3) within 30 days, complete a home study determining whether the relative should,
upon completion of training and submission of any other required documents, be
licensed as a foster parent.
One of three relative home studies reviewed was not completed within days of
placement. A corrective action plan is required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:

EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency was not required to submit any corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The DCWL analyst between the dates of 6/26/19 and 9/6/19 visited three foster
homes and three unlicensed relative homes. A total of four foster parents, three
unlicensed relatives, two foster children and six birth parents were interviewed.
Safety and Concerns Alerts
Safety and Concern Alert #1.
No concerns noted
Safety and Concern Alert #2.
The family has a pool and do not have an alarm on the door that leads to the pool.
The foster parents have their 12-year old niece placed in their home. According to
the foster parents they only became licensed for the placement of their niece and the
agency is scheduled to move child on 8/6/19. The foster parents also stated they
don’t intend to have other foster children in their home.
The agency was unable to contact the foster parent between 7/31/19 and 8/1/19 to
address the concern. The agency was advised by the foster parent on 8/1/19 that she
was camping, and the child was with her grandfather while she was camping. This
was confirmed by the assigned foster care worker. According to assigned foster care
worker the child was to be placed with another relative on 8/5/19. The agency was
planning to provide an alarm for the pool on 8/5/19 if the child was not placed with
another relative as planned. On 8/4/19 at approximately 4:10pm, CPS on call worker
completed a home visit with the foster parent and installed bells on the door leading
to the backyard which has a pool.
6

On 8/5/19 Foster Care worker reported that the child returned to the foster home on
Sunday (8/4/19) from being gone for the weekend. The foster care staff also
confirmed that the child was moved out of the home on 8/5/19.
Safety and Concern Alert #2a
The foster parent reported the licensing process took 7 months and once they
completed training it took 5 months for them to receive their license.
The agency reported that the children were placed in the home on 5/17/19 and the
home was licensed on 11/7/19.
7

The birth parent stated they were not notified of the child’s educational and medical
needs.
The agency reported the case record documented that the birth parent participated in
discussions regarding psychotropic medications for the children. The parent was
notified of all appointments when able to be contacted. The parent signed all but the
last two medical passports. The foster care worker attempted to have the parent
review and sign both documents. The medical passports were mailed to the parents
last known address. Information regarding the children’s education and medical
needs was also documented from FTMs and PATPs.
Safety and Concern Alert #3
A birth parent reported that they were not made aware of their child’s educational and
medical needs or involved in decisions regarding the child’s appearance.
The agency reported that the mother was incarcerated 10/15/18-6/14/19. She has
continued to be engaged in discussions regarding her child’s educational and medical
needs. She has signed medical passports and PATPs throughout the case. The
biological father participated in parenting time and FTMs for a period of time but
stopped attending parenting time and communication with the worker in May 2019.
Attempts to reengage the father through phone calls and face to face visits was
documented. PATPs were reviewed including information on the child, until the father
was unable to be located. After that time the PATP continued to be mailed to the
father despite the disconnect with services. No changes have taken place to the
child’s appearance.
Safety and Concern Alert #4
A relative caregiver said they were not made aware of available resources, such as
child daycare services.
The birth parent reported they were not informed of the child’s medical appointments.
The agency reported that the relative caregiver was provided a caregiver packet at
placement and the packet was reviewed with them by the assigned case manager. In
the packed is a publication which outlines the potential assistance that may be
available, including daycare assistance.
The parent was notified of her child’s follow up medical appointments at discharge
from the hospital and a duplicate copy with the well child appointment date was later
provided. It was also discussed with her after parenting time in July and she was
provided a list of appointments. This continues to be addressed with the medical
passport, PATPs and service plans.
Safety and Concern Alert #5.
8

No concerns
Safety and Concern Alert #6.
No concerns
Renewal inspection 2018
A renewal inspection was completed on 1/14/18. The renewal inspection made
the following findings.
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an operational statewide
automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the primary
tracking system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
The agency did not upload all required documents into MiSACWIS. This is a repeat
violation. A corrective action plan is required.
This interim inspection found the agency in compliance with this requirement.
ISEP 6.18 Page 23 Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness (Commitment
54).
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative foster parents within 180
days of the date of placement.
One of seven relative caregivers reviewed was licensed in excess of 180 days. A
corrective action plan is required.
This interim inspection found the agency compliant with requirement.
ISEP 5.1 – Page 14 Caseload Progressions for New Employees (Commitment
23).
b. For foster care and adoption workers, three training cases may be assigned on or
after day one of pre-service training at the supervisor’s discretion using CWTI case
assignments guidelines. After completion of week three of pre-service training, up to
five total cases may be assigned with supervisory approval using CWTI case
assignment guidelines. Final caseload may be assigned after nine weeks.
One new foster care worker was assigned 5 cases on the last day in the 9th week of
training exceeding 5 total cases. A corrective action plan is required.
This interim inspection found the agency compliant with this requirement.
9

DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C Page 2 Required Participation in Development -
Parents
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and service agreement, the
parent is given a copy for review. Foster care workers need to ensure the parent
understands all areas within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the PATP,
foster care workers must identify and document additional action needed to secure
the parent’s and/or youth’s participation in service planning and compliance with the
PATP. As the goals are achieved, modified or expanded, the updated PATP will reflect
this process. Parents and youths age 14 and older must participate in the development
of each updated treatment plan, allowing for opportunity to evaluate their progress
towards completing goals.
Nineteen service plans were reviewed. One caregiver PATP and two birth parent
PATPs were signed more than 30 days after the end of the report period. A corrective
action plan is required.
This interim inspection found the agency compliant with this requirement.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
